title: 104_s1877
content: The Act may be cited as the "Environmental Improvement Timber Contract Extension Act" and involves the modification of a long-term contract regarding the Tongass National Forest. The "Environmental Improvement Timber Contract Extension Act" modifies a long-term contract for the Tongass National Forest. Definitions include board feet, contract, contracting officer, and mid-market criteria. The "Environmental Improvement Timber Contract Extension Act" amends a contract for the Tongass National Forest, defining terms like mid-market criteria, proportionality, and purchaser (Ketchikan Pulp Company). The Forest Service and the purchaser, Ketchikan Pulp Company, entered into a contract to harvest 8,250,000,000 board feet of timber from the Tongass National Forest in Alaska. The contract is set to end in 2004, with the Forest Service intending to supply adequate timber. The contract between the Forest Service and Ketchikan Pulp Company aims to harvest 8,250,000,000 board feet of timber from the Tongass National Forest in Alaska. The Forest Service plans to provide timber for permanent operation of the purchaser's facilities on a commercially sound basis. A pulp mill is needed in southeast Alaska to create year-round, high-paying jobs and add high value to the area. The legislation aims to support the establishment of a pulp mill in southeast Alaska to create high-paying jobs, utilize low-grade wood, and enhance the regional economy. The purchaser plans to improve environmental practices and operations at the mill. The purchaser plans operational improvements to its pulp mill, including conversion to chlorine-free bleaching, wastewater treatment expansion, and power generation upgrades. Total capital expenditures are estimated at $200 million, with $25 million already invested. A 15-year contract extension is necessary for amortization of environmental and energy projects. Ketchikan is the fourth largest city in Alaska. The purchaser plans operational improvements to its pulp mill in Ketchikan, Alaska, including environmental and energy projects. A 15-year contract extension is needed for amortization. Ketchikan's economy relies heavily on the contract for year-round employment. The purchaser plans operational improvements to its pulp mill in Ketchikan, Alaska, including environmental and energy projects. Among its goals and objectives are the continuation of a long-term commitment to Ketchikan and southeast Alaska, participation in the Forest Service's land management planning process, and adherence to sound principles of multiple-use. The purchaser plans operational improvements to its pulp mill in Ketchikan, Alaska, including environmental and energy projects. Among its goals and objectives are participation in the Forest Service's land management planning process with other users for sustainable forest resource production and protection of air, water, and land. The national interest is served by a policy that focuses on protecting and promoting various forest uses in Alaska, such as tourism, fishing, subsistence, hunting, mining, and recreation. This includes compliance with environmental laws to protect air, water, and land, as well as a commitment to explore new technologies to maximize timber use and increase product value in southeast Alaska. The national interest is served by a policy that focuses on proper stewardship of publicly owned assets in the Tongass National Forest, ensuring a fair return for public timber, and maintaining a balance among multiple use interests to enhance forest health and economic growth in southeast Alaska and the United States. The contract in the Tongass National Forest is modified to extend the term by 15 years and include a sale offering plan to enhance forest health and economic growth in southeast Alaska and the United States. The contract in the Tongass National Forest is extended by 15 years and includes a sale offering plan detailing timber volume, location, and schedule for the purchaser. Volume requirements are set in 5-year increments of 962,500,000 board feet. The Tongass Land Management Plan must be coordinated with the extended contract in the Tongass National Forest, which sets timber volume requirements in 5-year increments of 962,500,000 board feet. The Forest Service will provide the purchaser with a yearly supply of at least 192,500,000 board feet until the next 5-year increment is given. The Forest Service will provide the purchaser with at least 192,500,000 board feet of timber per year to ensure a steady supply for harvesting. The contracting officer will also require the construction of roads by the purchaser in advance of the 5-year operating period to facilitate orderly harvest. The contracting officer will require the purchaser to construct roads in advance of the 5-year operating period for timber harvesting, with the roads included in the environmental impact statement. Timber selected for the 5-year increment must meet mid-market criteria. Appraisals and rates will be determined using normal national forest timber sale procedures. The contracting officer will designate rates for timber increments based on normal national forest procedures. Rates will not disadvantage the purchaser compared to similar enterprises in the Pacific Northwest. The Forest Service will measure proportionality using specific criteria. The purchaser shall only pay for timber provided. The Forest Service will measure proportionality based on specific criteria, including measuring by groups of contiguous management areas, acres, and over the entire rotation age. The purchaser has the option to convert or replace their pulp mill with a facility producing other value-added products. The purchaser has the option to convert or replace their pulp mill with a facility producing other value-added products. The unilateral termination clause of the contract is eliminated, and subsequent modifications require mutual agreement between the Forest Service and the purchaser. The contract, as modified by this subsection, can only be further changed by mutual agreement between the Forest Service and the purchaser, without needing an Act of Congress. The modifications will take effect 45 days after the enactment of the Act, and the contracting officer must update the contract text to reflect these changes by that date. The contracting officer must modify the contract to reflect changes made by subsection (c) and implement the modifications. Conforming changes must be made to ensure all modifications are implemented. Transition Timber Supply: Timber volume available under existing contracts will continue to be offered as modified by subsection (c), along with additional volume to meet the annual requirement of 192,500,000 board feet.
